items.title: Analysing Influencers with Sentiment Analysis
items.summary: This analysis was part of the joint article: Julián Castro-Rea and Juan Martinez, “Unlikely Influencers: Right-Wing Politics Online”. Paper presented…
items.content_html:
This analysis was part of the joint article:

Julián Castro-Rea and Juan Martinez, “Unlikely Influencers: Right-Wing Politics Online”. Paper presented to the 2023 Canadian Political Science Association Conference at York University, Toronto.

This article focuses on three right-wing political influencers, arguably the most popular in Canada: Jordan Peterson, Ben Shapiro and Andrew Tate. It will be argued that these three individuals, although very different from each other, are nonetheless jointly contributing in a major way to metapolitics...

A follow-up and discussion of these three men’s activities online over recent time will be offered. A computer-based, qualitative and quantitative measure of their impact is the basis for the analysis; tracking the content of their messaging, their number of followers and readership of their posts, and the impact these posts have on the followers. 

As part of this article, I extracted the post and corresponding comments in X (Twitter), Instagram and YouTube to measure:

  1. The type of "sentiment" by the influencers.
  2. The type of "sentiment" by users in social media.

The purpose was to understand further their approach to social media and how a user in these networks perceived their ideas.

The data was obtained in JSON format. Using a Python script the comments/texts were extracted and transformed to CSV.

For the sentiment analysis it was used is the Twitter-roBERTa-base which is based on around 124 million tweets in English from 2018 to 2021 as an input to train the algorithm (Python Script). This model is hosted and available in the Huggingface community and created by the Research Group in Natural Language Processing at Cardiff University (Huggingface 2023).

After analyzing around 2000 comments the results were visualized in bar charts using ggplot2 library in R. These are some of the plots created.

Based on the analysis and visualizations created, we made the following findings:

  1. Although Andrew Tate's polemic figure, his publications show a more balanced set of emotions in his publications. Similarly is the reaction of the users.
  2. In the cases of Ben Shapiro and Jordan Peterson, they use more negative language when expressing their ideas while receiving similar reactions from the users.

items.title: Edmonton Housing Investment Analysis
items.summary: The principal objective of this project was to identify vacant publicly owned land that would be suitable for future community…
items.content_html:
The principal objective of this project was to identify vacant publicly owned land that would be suitable for future community housing development. Amidst the cost-of-living crisis currently being faced by Canadian communities, it is important to identify derelict properties being underutilized to aid in appeasing low-income housing demand. The output of this analysis will provide a list of suitable sites in which community housing may be developed.

Methodology

A suitability analysis was used to assess the quality of publicly owned vacant land in Edmonton.

  • Factors that affect the suitability of low-income housing were developed based on research from Nanjing University (Fang et al., 2022), and the city of Edmonton
    website for affordable housing, presented in Table 1.
  • Weighted score criteria from the factors were created and weights were assigned
    using a 1-10 scale and scores were given for more suitable situations.
  • Using the weighted score criteria, the values of the dissemination blocks were
    spatially joined with a 50 m x 50 m fishnet grid in ArcGIS and an overall score was given for each cell, creating a heat map which highlights the most suitable zones.
  • The sites located within the most suitable cells were then differentiated by their
    vacant lot size in square meters and as a result of the above operations a map
    demonstrating the sites was created.

The following are the four locations recommended based on both a quantitative and qualitatitive analysis.

items.title: Visualizing History: Text Analysis of U.S. Diplomatic Cables about human rights violations in Colombia
items.summary: Vision: To help rebuild Colombian history related to the inner conflict. Objective: Create a data set of locations mentioned in…
items.content_html:
Vision: To help rebuild Colombian history related to the inner conflict.

Objective: Create a data set of locations mentioned in U.S Diplomatic Cables released and hosted by the National Digital National Security Archive. 

This project is a proof of concept. In this project over 80 declassified diplomatic cables issued in 1999 by the United States Embassy located in Bogota, Colombia was transformed to digital text. The locations mentioned in these documents were extracted to provide insights into the geographical scope of the U.S. interest in the Colombian conflict and human rights violations.

The overall process was the following:

Original files were scanned images in PDF format. The first step was to extract the text through OCR using gImageReader to clean and extract the text into text files. After that using a Python script location names were extracted and geolocated with latitude and longitude coordinates. This data was cleansed manually using a combination of QGIS, MS Excel and R. 

Additionally, the most frequent human rights violation terms were counted and grouped into four categories: those related to murder, drugs, kidnapping and others. Using Python these categories were related to each observation.

Ultimately, the database created includes the name of the original file, location name, longitude, latitude, and the word categories including a count of each of them. 

Limitations and scope:

  1. Observations (rows) are based on a unique combination of "name of file" and "location". This means that even if a place is presented multiple times in a document, it will be counted as one.
  2. This data is obtained from U.S. documents, which means that every insight is from this country and the government's point of view.
  3. It is challenging to detect and clean locations on a global scale. There are multiple locations across the world with the same name, as there are people and families with such names. There was an extensive effort to clean errors and miss-placed locations. Please make contact in case of finding any mistake.

The dataset is accessible in Dataverse Here (Pending approval).

INTERACTIVE MAPS

These maps were created using QGIS and show the locations mentioned across the world by country, and in Colombia. Also, words related to crime and criminality were  counted and grouped across the documentation, then add up based on group, name me of the location and name of the file.
